content.title: Non-Occlusive Mesenteric Ischemia (NOMI): Comprehensive ICU Management
content.summary: NOMI represents 20-30% of acute mesenteric ischemia but carries the highest mortality (70-90%). It occurs without mechanical occlusion, instead resulting from splanchnic vasoconstriction in critically ill patients.

etiology.primary_mechanism: Splanchnic vasoconstriction due to low-flow states
high_risk_settings: Post-cardiac surgery (especially CABG and valve procedures)
Septic shock with high vasopressor requirements

pathophysiology.mechanism: Prolonged mesenteric vasoconstriction outlasts the precipitating event
unique_features: Can persist even after hemodynamic optimization
May be patchy rather than involving entire vascular territory

clinical_features.presentation: Often masked by underlying critical illness and sedation
subtle_signs: Rising lactate despite apparent hemodynamic stability
clinical_features.classic_patient: Post-cardiac surgery patient on day 2-5 with unexplained deterioration

imaging.cta_findings: May show diffuse arterial narrowing ('string of sausages' sign), bowel wall thickening, but NO filling defect
imaging.challenge: Absence of occlusion can lead to false reassurance

diagnosis.angiography: Characteristic pruning of mesenteric branches with slow flow

hemodynamic_optimization.goal: Optimize cardiac output rather than MAP alone
actions: Inotropes preferred over vasopressors when possible
Consider dobutamine for cardiac output enhancement
Target MAP 65-70 mmHg with lowest vasopressor dose
Adequate volume resuscitation before vasopressor escalation

considerations: Transition from norepinephrine to less vasoconstrictive agents if feasible
Avoid vasopressin if possible (significant mesenteric constriction)
Consider milrinone for inotropic support (less vasoconstriction)

glucagon.evidence: Limited but may be tried as rescue therapy

surgical_indications: Clinical deterioration despite maximal medical therapy

prognosis.mortality: 70-90% - highest of all mesenteric ischemia types

prevention_strategies: Early enteral feeding in ICU patients when feasible
Judicious vasopressor use with regular reassessment
Adequate hemodynamic resuscitation before major surgery
Monitoring for early signs in high-risk patients
content.clinical_significance: NOMI has the highest mortality of all mesenteric ischemia types and is often recognized late due to masking by critical illness - awareness and early intervention are key to improving outcomes
